newsitem.title: HONG KONG: China rate cut to impact in longer term - analysts.
newsitem.headline: China rate cut to impact in longer term - analysts.

text.p: China's intention to cut bank lending rates by 1.2 percentage points from Friday was well received but it would not impact immediately on state-owned companies nor the economy, analysts said on Thursday.
"There has always been a time lag and the effect from China's first interest rate cut in May has not surfaced yet," said Joanne Yim, economic research manager with Hang Seng Bank.

But expectations of the imminent rate cut have already boosted shares of Hong Kong-listed China companies on Thursday, with the H-share index closing at a 12-week high on hopes of improved business conditions.
China would cut bank deposit rates by 1.5 percent and lending rates by 1.2 percentage points from Friday.

An official China newspaper which reported on Thursday that conditions were ripe for a further interest rate cut pushed the H-share index to close at 841.17, up 21.95 points or nearly three percent, brokers said.

"It's very good news for the (H-share) companies and I'm turning more positive though I have been positive since April," Ching Ju Yeh, a senior investment manager with HSBC Asset Management Asia-Pacific Ltd, said.
HSBC Asset manages five China funds with a total size of US$50 million.
But Yeh said she would not rush to push up the H-share rating in HSBC funds, which account for between eight to 10 percent of the company's China fund portfolio.

"It helps sentiment but I wouldn't say that's the only factor for me to consider to put more money in the sector," she said, adding that some H-share companies were still burdened with structural problems which need time to resolve.
Economists and analysts said lower interest rates would help ease interest payment burdens of many state-owned industrial companies in China.
But an analyst at a European house said long-term bank loans allocated to state-owned companies would normally have their rates fixed at the drawdown and for usual periods of five years.
"Those companies that borrowed short-term working capital might benefit," he added.
Analysts said an interest rate cut would not necessarily mean easier and cheaper credit for companies.
But Hang Seng's Yim said the Chinese economy would benefit as a whole from the rate cut since this would be a sign for further easing of monetary policy.
"Many of the state-owned enterprises are facing operational problems due to the lack of working capital and heavy financial burden under higher interest rates," Yim said.
In the first quarter of 1996, China's state sector made a net loss of 3.0 billion yuan, the first deficit since paramount leader Deng Xiaopeng launched market reforms 17 years ago.
